history.content:
Hi! I'm currently a senior LSCS major in need of some life advice. I'm conflicted between recruiting right now and focusing on getting things done for applying to a masters. Here's context:

1) I interned at a super cool start up this summer and did full stack web development and didn't love it. I definitely enjoy coding and learning and implementing algorithms, but i dont want my days to be opening PR’s to change the background of a button to use the rgb function instead of a hex value....

2) After taking CS 170, I've begun to really see the beauty in the math/theory parts of my courses (with the exception of maybe crypto in 161 lol) and have started chasing math.

I was thinking of taking an extra year to do a minor in math because its so cool, while getting the rec letters and some research experience (I have an inside source to almost guarantee that if i do well in my classes this year i will get into a cool research lab this summer) to apply to a masters. But I'm unsure. That's 2-3 years of industry experience (worst case, if i do 0 more internships during my masters) I won't have.

I also have thought CS161 is really cool and love working on web/network related things so I'd be down to stay like an extra semester and take classes like CS162 CS168 Math 110 and CS261 that might help me get a leg up there and go into industry after next Fall or something. But what do cybersecurity or security jobs in general even look like? What should I even do to prepare for such a thing if I decide on that route? Is it too late?

My biggest concern is that since I'm going ham in my classes to try to get good grades, I'm not necessarily recruiting rn (and instead trying to focus on getting A's). Is this a mistake? I feel directionless not having made up my find and I'm not even sure how I would without risking delaying my graduation date or ending up with a somewhat mediocre result. What do people think? I know at least 2 of my friends are struggling to make similar decisions...
history.subject: Masters vs industry advice
